tags: dont mind me im having feelings
summary: I like to think that Aziraphale and Crowley fight sometimes. not real fights, they couldn't bare the pain of being seriously...
body:
I like to think that Aziraphale and Crowley fight sometimes. not real fights, they couldn’t bare the pain of being seriously angry at each other, but like old-married couple fights, over the most stupid stuff

and maybe they try to act mad and not talk to each other for a couple of days but fail miserably. maybe at one point Aziraphale steals one of Crowley’s most expensive colognes by miracling it out of his flat and into the bookshop, just so that Crowley can call an hour later and ask “did you take my cologne?” “well, I gave it to you in the first place, I thought it was time to take it back” “you liar, I bought it myself, doesn’t the bible say something against lying and stealing?” “it says nothing against stealing from demons who think flamingos really have just one leg” and after some more petty comments they end up laughing and make plans for tomorrow’s lunch

they’re idiots

blog.name: en-sam-malas
blog.title: ineffable
blog.description:
☆ bi-aro, multifandom, she/her, Filipino ★

my writing tag || Hugabug & en-sam-malas on ao3 ☆

summary: in lieu of Aziraphale Pulling Breadcrumbs Out Of His Top Hat I give you--
body:
in lieu of Aziraphale Pulling Breadcrumbs Out Of His Top Hat I give you–

the Aziraphale Does Not Use Objects For Their Intended Uses Because He Genuinely Does Not Understand Their Intended Use™️ bullet point headcanons:

  • I know that that little bit was put in perhaps as foreshadowing for his magic show later on but I am also under the impression that…
  • He simply stores food in his top hat. We know that. We’ve seen it. He doesn’t understand why it has so much room with such a tiny brim. But there is so much space inside, perhaps it is made to be storage? Pastries and sandwiches. Sometimes a biscuit or two. The crumbs in his otherwise immaculate hair is just a small price to pay.
  • He is not flexible– must we remind you that Crowley is the snake, not he? Oh no, his arms cannot reach behind him relieve himself of that dreadful itch. It’s why he uses a wooden spoon. In fact, he keeps it close and it goes everywhere with him around the shop and the flat. Anywhere but the kitchen.
  • He has a trumpet hanging from one of the bookshelves in his shop. He doesn’t play. It’s his special vase– there are new fresh flowers in there every other day (courtesy of a rather amorous serpent) and it’s mouthpiece never drips water even if it probably should. (Crowley suspects Azira does to objects what he does to plants– except politely, of course. And nicer. That trumpet is so well behaved.)
  • He does not fold the pages of books. But he owns no bookmarks. Crowley has once found a sock pressed into the pages of an original copy of the Divine Comedy.
  • Crowley’s taken to giving him cassettes instead of Vinyls or CDs– both tend to end up as coasters or chargers at one point. It’s horrendous.
  • The gramophone has birds nesting in it. Crowley doesn’t even know how they got in there. He despairs.
  • A fork? To comb his wings? That he had started using because the brush was too far away? Oh, you bet.
  • No wonder they’re so ill-kept.
  • Crowley gave him a mobile phone at one point. And at one point he had found it in the refrigerator. Where all his other gifts to Azira that he does not use are stored.
  • Crowley had bought him an iPad once. He’d used it as a tray for hot cocoa.
  • He.
  • Sits.
  • On.
  • Top.
  • Of.
  • Anything.
  • Including a chair, the top of said refrigerator, on top of shelves and on dangerously teetering piles of books.
  • You’d think Crowley is bad. Azira is worse. At least Crowley does it in snake form and because he’s a cheeky bastard. Azira does it because he genuinely thinks it’s acceptable.
  • Pencils he uses like thumbtacks. They intimidate customers, when they come in and find an otherwise mild mannered man drive a pencil into the wall just to hang a flier of nonsense all the while making intense eye contact. But it’s become a habit. Crowley refuses to buy him any more pencils.
  • That’s alright. He does it with pens, too.

reblog.comment:

summary: Aziraphale, a playlist by Anežka Koudelová on Spotify
body:
So hello people, i have made a playlist for my boy Aziraphale cause i haven’t seen any just for him yet, which is a bleeding shame. It’s centered on Aziraphale’s feeling for Crowley. I think I’ll make one for Crowley too eventually… if i get motivated enough.

blog.name: seraph5
blog.title: Tumbling Like Alice
blog.description: Hey this is Cara! I'm a Melbournite and this blog will mostly consist of fanart and long silences when I get trapped out in the real world. There will be a lot of whatever ship is setting my world on fire and whatever ships always have. Peace, love and mung beans, friends.

summary: Crimson & Obscene (or The Obligatory Bright Young Things AU) Chapter 3: “Mad, Bad & Dangerous to Know” “I never considered how...
caption:
Crimson & Obscene (or The Obligatory Bright Young Things AU)

Chapter 3: “Mad, Bad & Dangerous to Know”

“I never considered how beautiful it really was until… Well, until I saw how it all was affecting you. But don’t worry,” Miles teased, smiling as he lightly knocked his shoulder against Crowley’s, “I won’t tell anyone that you cried. I know you have a reputation to uphold.”

“Well, I should hope my reputation includes an appreciation for the arts,” Crowley sniffed as they ventured toward the coat check, handing off their tickets to the attendant. Smirking, he mused, “Let the busybodies talk all they want about my crying at the opera. Perhaps they’ll stop hypothesizing about every other aspect of my life.”

“Oh, that’s hardly likely,” Miles disagreed as he took his coat and scarf from the attendant, winding the blue silk around his neck before shrugging into the white pea coat and doing up the buttons. After allowing Crowley a moment to slip into his own black overcoat, the two of them set out into the cool, damp evening. Just a few days more and spring would be upon them…

“Why do you say that it’s unlikely?” Crowley asked as they waited for the valet to fetch his car. Hands in his pockets, he looked down at Miles with a deftly arched eyebrow. Miles just smiled.

“Because, my dear Anthony, you’re everyone’s favourite subject. The mysterious Mr. Crowley, with his secret fortune and private Mayfair flat that no one has ever stepped foot in; you’re positively a local fascination.”

The look in Miles’ eyes was entirely coquettish; it was no coincidence that he mentioned that no one had ever stepped foot in Crowley’s flat. He was fishing for an invitation, hoping to be the first to break into his secret little world. Unfortunately, no invitation came; instead, Crowley just smirked and asked, “Am I your favourite subject?”

“Only in the most confidential of company,” Miles hemmed (meaning Agatha).

“And do you find me fascinating?”

“Oh, exceedingly.”

Smiling, Miles tossed Crowley a wink as the valet pulled up with the Bentley, allowing the two of them to slide into the car’s warmth and out of London’s late-winter dampness.

As they drove, Miles found himself watching from the corner of his eye as Crowley tugged his white gloves off with his teeth before tossing each one in turn into the backseat. Not exactly the most refined way of doing things, but it was the most enrapturing. Delicately plucking his own off one finger at a time, Miles let his gaze properly settle on Crowley when the redhaired gentleman asked, “What would you like to know?”

“Sorry?”

“You said you find me exceedingly fascinating,” Crowley clarified, tapping his fingers against the Bentley’s steering wheel as he drove, the gold of his ruby ring clicking against the mahogany as he did so. “I assume that means you’re curious.”

“Well, yes. Obviously,” Miles agreed, his cheeks turning slightly pink as he added, “But I’m not presumptuous. I know you like having your secrets. What right have I to them?”

“I do like having my secrets… but maybe I’d also like having a confidant,” Crowley mused, pausing the tapping of his ring to peek over at Miles, his lips quirking upwards at the way the other gentleman’s jaw dropped ever-so-slightly. “After all, it’s not as if you’re that infamous Mr. Chatterbox, eh? I’m sure I can trust you.”

“Of course you can,” Miles breathed, the words coming out rather like a squeak.

“Then I’ll ask you again: what would you like to know?”

Read the full chapter on AO3
